What do you think?

The functions inside the actions hash are copied and bound to a special object when you call `addAction(s)` or when you pass them to the `Flux` constructor. See https://github.com/BinaryMuse/fluxxor/blob/d35b6046fdafc9385ee30de1d9ae542ae592ec07/lib/flux.js#L33-42 and https://github.com/BinaryMuse/fluxxor/blob/master/lib/flux.js#L68.

I'll elaborate my tweet-replies here.
- Perhaps drop the "fluxxor" prefix on the props because it's implicit. And if you're afraid of naming clashes (while I believe a library may reserve relevant prop-names, like `stores`) instead of `props` you could use a less common prop-name for example `queries`, `loaders` or even a verb like `initialize`.
- Try to avoid using abbreviations like in `fluxxorExtraCtx`. Personally I would prefer `extraContext` or something totally different that's more specific.
- A reason to use the Higher-order component (HOC) syntax instead of declaring controller properties as static is to support for multiple instances of that controller. I discovered that while writing [react-transmit](https://github.com/RickWong/react-transmit). In the above static example `RecipeList` controller would only be useful once, because its stores and props are defined statically. It would not be possible to change how the `recipes` prop is initialized. If you try to use the controller twice, they would by definition both get the same data. Higher-order components on the other hand have their own state, so they can be programmed at run-time to listen to other stores or have a specific prop initializer like the above `<FluxxorController fluxxorStores=... />` example.

@BinaryMuse You are absolutely on the right track about deprecating mixins in favor of wrapper components (I call them "adapters", i.e. FluxxorAdapter, to avoid "controller" and other MVC parlance). You might find some inspiration below, if you haven't read these posts already:
- [Why FluxComponent > fluxMixin](https://github.com/acdlite/flummox-immutable-store/blob/master/docs/why-flux-component-is-better-than-flux-mixin.md)
- [Mixins Are Dead. Long Live Composition](https://medium.com/@dan_abramov/mixins-are-dead-long-live-higher-order-components-94a0d2f9e750)

Looking forward to see what you will come up with. I would embrace ES6 for the Fluxxor store as well, i.e. have a `Fluxxor.Store` class instead of a `Fluxxor.createStore()` function, but that's just me.

Fluxxor doesn't require React to be in the global namespace; in fact, most of Fluxxor doesn't depend on React. When React _is_ required, you're expected [to pass it in](http://fluxxor.com/documentation/flux-mixin.html) (so you can get it however you want‚ÄîCommonJS, global, etc.)

- store binds events to functions, which set data in the store based on results

I can't thank you enough for taking the time to write this lengthy explanation. It helped me debug something nasty in my code. 

In the hope It helps somebody one day:

I had a factory (or so I thought) creating a base store with a couple of things I want to use in every store. Little did I realize that requirejs creates a singleton no matter what.

My factory was, in effect, just a single ton and all my stores added their own functions to it  ( with lodash merge) including the actions....and the listeners. That's why events where triggered multiple times: each of my store had a listener for each available action.

`StoreWatchMixin` was changed in 1c703259485c0d5cf73ad85492e0da0ad172fade to bind to events in `componentDidMount` instead of `componentWillMount` because `willMount` is called on the server, making it easier to leak memory (#88). I failed to update the documentation to match, and I will fix that.

The React docs [suggest firing Ajax requests from `didMount`](http://facebook.github.io/react/docs/component-specs.html#mounting-componentdidmount), though I understand it's nice to be able to get that loading state in the initial state rather than changing it after the fact. If that's something you really want and server rendering is not a concern for you, you might consider just rolling a special version of `StoreWatchMixin` that uses `willMount` instead; it's [a fairly small/simple module](https://github.com/BinaryMuse/fluxxor/blob/3c4b278c4944f5b7b5c24f8d8d8204c40239e2fb/lib/store_watch_mixin.js).
Good to know!  Thank you very much.

Unfortunately, this problem seems to pop up fairly often when components dispatch actions in their `componentWill/DidMount` hooks, especially when routes change in response to an action, as the dispatch loop hasn't completed by the time the component mounts.

As you've said, one quick fix is to wrap some portion of the process in a `setTimeout`. Depending on your setup, you might experiment with making either the `transitionTo()` call or the second action dispatch (the one that happens in your dashboard component) async in this manner. While I normally recommend against this practice, as it defeats the purpose of the assertion, the practice falls down a bit in this situation. I would probably _not_ make the `emit` call async, as that completely sidesteps the assertion in _all_ cases, when in fact you only want to sidestep it in the routing/mounting case.

Another pattern I've been using more often when a component needs to get initial data from a flux store is to fetch the data from the store instead of firing an action when the component mounts. If the store doesn't have the data cached/ready, it can fetch it asynchronously and then dispatch an action when it's available. Here's a basic example: https://gist.github.com/BinaryMuse/3b0a4ba166ac81840cab This allows you to remove the dispatch when the component mounts.

Thanks for your work on Fluxxor, @BinaryMuse! I came here to report the same problem and noticed this GitHub issue. A few days ago at React.js Conference I spoke with Michael Jackson of rackt/react-router about it. His take on this (as I recall) was that actions are not meant to be long-lived in this manner.

I'm sure there's a reason Fluxxor assumes the role of preventing multiple actions, but there is an obvious conflict here with an extremely common use case. (Save data on a page with an action, route to new page as a result, perform new action when the next page loads.)

Using `setTimeout` or async routing is just putting a bandaid on the problem. Would you be open to a modification of Fluxxor's behavior? I'd be glad to try my hand at it and submit a PR.

Since action handlers are synchronous, a handler is finished with an action when it returns (either explicitly by `return`ing something or implicitly by returning `undefined` when the function finishes). I agree that the docs/examples could be improved here.

This is not a pattern that Fluxxor is likely to "officially" support out of the box, but there are a couple options you have:

1) Capture all the data from each store at some top-level and then pass it down

You said that you have to call each store from your components and compile the data; a popular pattern is to do this only once at the top-level component and then pass that whole state down (which is essentially what it sounds like you're trying to do with the single master store). Let your individual stores handle actions like normal, and have some extra module that watches for the change events, aggregates all the data, and then notifies the React app that the data has changed.

2) Manually handle dispatches with a "custom" store

The dispatcher calls `Store#__handleAction__(action)` when it dispatches to a store; the store returns `true` if it handled the action. You could create your own object that defines a custom `__handleAction__` that just forwards the dispatch to each store. Note, however, that this API is private, meaning it could change from under you without a major version number change.

I'm also curious of the relationship between two dispatchers of Fluxxor and of [Facebook](https://github.com/facebook/flux/blob/master/src%2FDispatcher.js).

That's a good set of questions, @SammyK; I can't promise I have all the answers right now, but I'm happy to discuss it. (This may seem more like a thought dump than a real answer to your question, probably because it will be, but hopefully the answers will be in here somewhere. :)

The original goal for Fluxxor was just to make concrete some of the vague notions of what a flux-based application would really look like; this was when all we really had was the todo example. After playing with the pattern myself and talking to engineers both on and off the FB team, I decided that the best way to solidify what flux would look like was to make a library to reify the concepts‚Äîand experience had shown that it was likely others were in the same boat, and would benefit from the project. Thus, Fluxxor was born.

The core of Fluxxor is really the dispatcher-action-store trio; basically, everything you get when you do `new Fluxxor.Flux(stores, actions)`. The mixins, and the role of `context`, are really secondary; I considered making the mixins their own project, but I found them useful enough to include them in the main Fluxxor codebase. My hope was that, over time, people would create (and maybe publish) their own mixins for the patterns they found themselves using over and over (whether it be passing the Flux instance around or better watching of stores, etc.), and I in no way meant for `FluxMixin`/`FluxChildMixin` to be the "right" way to get access to your Flux instance.

I agree that in a strict, 100% "pure" React/flux app, you'd probably pass everything around via props. However, in practice, I find that quite tedious; one of the reasons I gave flux a shot was to avoid the need for passing callbacks deep down into the component hierarchy. Granted, the callbacks being "bundled together" into the `actions` hash helps a lot, but I still think there's probably a place for being able to get access to the actions without passing them explicitly in props.

In the flux demos that the FB team has posted, they use CommonJS requires to access singleton instances of stores and actions. You could do basically the same thing with Fluxxor (e.g. `module.exports = new Fluxxor.Flux(...)`). I'm not a fan of the "global singleton" approach as a default, because it makes it harder to do e.g. multiple instances of an app or sub-app on a single page, or isolated instances of a flux app on the server. Instead, I tended to make my React application itself the container for the flux system; I found `context` to be a useful tool for doing so‚Äîessentially, `getFlux().actions` was an application-wide publisher to the flux system.

Another thing to keep in mind (though it may be tangential to this discussion) is that it is sometimes useful to have a view-controller (a component that gets data from stores and watches for change events) deeper in the component hierarchy; [the flux article talks about this a bit as well](http://facebook.github.io/react/docs/flux-overview.html#views-and-controller-views):

> Occasionally we may need to add additional controller-views deeper in the hierarchy to keep components simple. This might help us to better encapsulate a section of the hierarchy related to a specific data domain. ... In making the decision of whether to add a deep controller-view, balance the gain of simpler components against the complexity of multiple data updates flowing into the hierarchy at different points.

So, circling around to the start, it's probably useful to think about what Fluxxor's goals are now that the pattern is a bit more well understood and there are a few choices for implementing flux in your own applications. As of right now, my thoughts are:
1. To make the flux pattern obvious via concrete implementation of each of the pieces of a typical flux architecture
2. To provide the basic flux guarantees (in particular, no cascading dispatches)
3. To make working with a flux-based application easy, reducing repetitive boilerplate as much as possible
4. To do the above while still providing a flexible/extensible library (e.g., action types/payloads will probably always be JSON serializable for using them in web workers/across the network)

@guersam The Fluxxor dispatcher doesn't really have a relationship with the Facebook one. Fluxxor's is more tightly integrated into the Fluxxor stores (which is something that I probably should and will change), while Facebook's is going to be more generic, since you can hook it up to any callback.

But seeing all the examples and discussing it with people like you has really helped me to solidify the Flux pattern even more. Now I think I can summarize Flux in a few sentences:

> Flux is a design pattern in which a component (the view-controller) listens for change events on a store and triggers `setState()` on itself with every change. React will automatically rerender all the kid components (the views) that get immutable store state objects via props. Actions simply link the views to the dispatcher and the dispatcher makes sure it doesn't go all to hell.

I think that's the essence of Flux. :)

That's a great question, @jsilvestre.

Flux is really all about managing the flow of data in the system‚Äîensuring that store state changes _only_ take place in response to an action dispatch. Preventing "cascading updates" is one of the ways flux helps prevent confusing data flows; what this means is you can't dispatch a second action _from inside another action handler_. It's the thick red line in the top of this diagram that should be prevented:

![Cascading Dispatch](https://www.evernote.com/shard/s23/sh/66e02880-8d24-45a9-bf4a-7a8a1c7a3b8c/35474513410557323ada90f8ff080326/deep/0/flux-cascading-dispatch.png)

Fluxxor specifically does _not_ prevent side-by-side dispatches on the same tick of the event loop (it used to, but this changed in version 1.2.0). Since XHR and websocket handlers run asynchronously, you shouldn't run into issues dispatching actions from inside them.

Please feel free to re-open this issue if you have more questions or something doesn't appear to be working correctly.

@arathunku, dispatching multiple side-by-side actions, or dispatching additional actions in response to an asynchronous event, is fine. You could send the `REQUEST_LOAD` and `REQUEST_FINISH` actions, as in your example, or you could tell the `RequestStore` (or whatever it is) to watch for the individual `*_LOAD`, `*_SUCCESS`, and `*_ERROR` actions. I think either approach is valid depending on how many different actions you have and how you want to manage them.

Another thought is to push the dispatching of the `REQUEST_LOAD` and `REQUEST_FINISH` actions into some higher-level communications abstraction, so that any time you make a request or a request finishes those actions are automatically dispatched.

But later this listener called by EventEmitter like it was never removed.

The two main causes of the extraneous changes were avoiding React's triggering of jsdom's "Wrong Document" error [1] and using FluxChildMixin and FluxMixin. Okay, I did a bit of digging into this issue. Here's what's happening to cause the bug:
1. Parent component `willMount` hook called
   1. Parent component registers change event handler on Store1, Store2
2. Child component `willMount` hook called
   1. Child component registers change event handler on Store1
3. Action is dispatched
4. Store1 handles action, fires `change` event
   1. EventEmitter [gets an array of all the event handlers](https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/832d4db5f221705f8a1058a6aa3e4bcc9a5de8ad/lib/events.js#L126) ‚Äî note that this is a _copy_ of the internal handlers list
   2. EventEmitter [starts calling handlers](https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/832d4db5f221705f8a1058a6aa3e4bcc9a5de8ad/lib/events.js#L128-129) in a loop
5. Parent component handles event, sets state from `getStateFromFlux` and re-renders due to new state ‚Äî Child is no longer part of the render tree
6. Child component `willUnmount` hook called
   1. Child component removes `change` event handler on Store1 ‚Äî but it doesn't matter, because the list of handlers has already been built in step 4
7. Second event handler from the step 4 array is called
8. Since the Child was unmounted, the call to `setState` throws

Based on joyent/node#7872, this is the intended behavior in `EventEmitter`, so guarding against this in Fluxxor is necessary.

Just wanted to pop in for a quick update here.

There's no doubt that this functionality is quite useful from a reusable abstractions standpoint, but I've always been hesitant to merge it in due to the complexity that mixins bring (similar to the complexity they brought to React). As you probably know, there's been a big push toward native ES6 classes from the React team, and using native classes in React 0.13 precludes the use of mixins (as provided by `React.createClass`), with the goal of utilizing more idiomatic JS patterns to implement that functionality in the future (or using composition instead).

Furthermore, a future version of Fluxxor is likely to provide a more flexible method of store creation, which will include less "magic," and I'm not sure how this particular feature will fit in to that effort. So, for now, I'm going to leave this unmerged, but rest assured that making reusable store patterns easier to implement is definitely on my mind going forward.

This is a really interesting question that I hadn't considered. My initial reaction was to say that Fluxxor doesn't place any constraints on your store implementations, allowing you to implement rollback yourself. After thinking about it, I started to think that the idea of a "transaction" (or some other way of indicating a failure during a dispatch) may be useful. However, dispatches are synchronous, and the main case where a dispatch will fail is in asynchronous code; I'm guessing that you'd need to fire a separate action to indicate a failure, but I'm not 100% sure how best to do this (e.g. how do you identify the data that changed with a message indicating failure w/o holding on to that data forever).

I'm going to think on it some more and build some more examples to exercise the issue; if you have any particular examples yourself (working code is especially useful :) I'd love to have your input!

> 'm guessing that you'd need to fire a separate action to indicate a failure, but I'm not 100% sure how best to do this (e.g. how do you identify the data that changed with a message indicating failure w/o holding on to that data forever)

In the current implementation Fluxxor (please correct if wrong) only 1 action is allowed at a time by the dispatcher. Otherwise an error is thrown. 

Although I'm still uncertain if this is the correct way for async store operations (your question and accepted answer on SO seems to strengthen my thought that it's not, see: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23635964/how-do-you-manage-asynchronous-store-operations-with-flux) this may greatly simplify doing rollbacks: 

A very naive rollback could be done by just storing the previous state of all stores. If one of the stores fail, rollback to the previous stored state. Since no two actions can interfere, there's no need to keep a long history of store-states but only the previous one .

I'm sure this doesn't cover the general case, but just wanted to jot this down for now.

As soon as you enter asynchronous code, you're no longer "in the current dispatch," and another dispatch can be made on the next tick (otherwise a long-running Ajax request could block actions caused by user interactions while it's still pending). So "only one action is allowed at a time" does _not_ include asynchronous actions, which in turn means there's no way to associate an asynchronous failure with a particular action at the dispatcher level (in the current implementation).

Hey, @lorefnon,

Thanks for the issue‚Äîthis has come up a couple times, and I should probably include it in the docs. I actually had the same thought when I first started experimenting with flux; they definitely are another layer of indirection, though I'm now not so sure they're superfluous.

You actually can dispatch actions directly if you want via `getFlux().dispatcher.dispatch`, but that couples the component to:
- the dispatcher implementation
- the action type (i.e. the string itself)
- the format of the payload

In a larger application, the extra indirection will make changes to the action/data layer easier without having to change your application's components. It also allows changes to the Fluxxor dispatcher without needing to change either (1) your components (because they don't know about the dispatcher at all) or (2) your action methods (because `this.dispatch` is bound to an internal object that handles actually doing the dispatch for you).

Related to the first point above, the actions also give you semantically meaningful method names: `flux.actions.addUrl(url)` instead of `flux.dispatcher.dispatch(Actions.ADD_URL, {url: url})`.

See also [Creating Semantic Actions](http://facebook.github.io/react/docs/flux-todo-list.html#creating-semantic-actions-) on the React site:

> As you can see, we really would not need to have the helpers AppDispatcher.handleViewAction() or TodoActions.create(). We could, in theory, call AppDispatcher.dispatch() directly and provide a payload. But as our application grows, having these helpers keeps the code clean and semantic. It's just a lot cleaner to write TodoActions.destroy(id) instead of writing a whole lot of things that our TodoItem shouldn't have to know about.

Hope that helps; this is a really interesting topic to me, so feel free to keep thinking about/discussing it!

Hey, @dariocravero,
1. At minimum, any controller-views in the system would need to have access to the stores to watch for change events and get new state from them. It is possible to have controller-views down inside your component hierarchy, depending on your application structure. Maybe there's a good way to enforce the read-don't-write nature of the stores; it's worth exploring.
2. `getFlux()` is an abstraction that allows you to get at the flux instance no matter which mixin you used. For the instance to show up on child components' `context`, they have to declare it in their `contextTypes`, and I'd rather `context` simply be an implementation detail (especially since the context API is not actually public or finalized). A few random thoughts about this:

First, our objective is to build an isomorphic app, so we want to render an HTML page on the server which contains fully rendered React views and which has Javascript which prepopulates all the stores and then calls into React to hook up our event handlers.

My first thought is that we probably do not want to run the same `actions` on the client and server; the client side may do Ajax requests which go fetch data from the server, but server side we don't want to send HTTP Ajax requests to ourselves; we want to replace these calls with synchronous or asynchronous calls.  Server side there also may not be any need to fire a bunch of actions through flux in the first place, as it may be more desirable to just build an initial view of the stores through plain old sync and async calls.

If we head this way, note that if your components use `FluxMixin` or `StoreWatchMixin`, then you must pass a `flux` instance to your components, even when rendering them on the server, because these two classes try to find `flux` in `componentWillMount()` which is called on both the client and the server.  It's tempting to say that in the case of `StoreWatchMixin`, [this block](https://github.com/BinaryMuse/fluxxor/blob/master/lib/store_watch_mixin.js#L7-L10) should be moved to `componentDidMount()`, which is only called client side - this way server side we can just pre-populate the stores and we don't need to bother hooking up any listeners.  Alternatively, StoreWatchMixin could take an optional parameter `listenToStoresOnServer` which controls whether this is done in `componentWillMount()` or `componentDidMount()`.

Rendering the react components on the server is straightforward, but we also need to marshal the contents of the stores into a JSON string that we can pass down to the client.  Ideally this should be straightforward without having to write a lot of boilerplate code.  Stores can store data fairly arbitrarily, though.  Perhaps if we defined a `toJSON()` and a `fromJSON(jsonString)` on each Store, then on the server we could call `flux.storesToJSON()` to get a big JSON object of all the stores, which we could embed in a `<script>` tag, then client side call `flux.storesFromJSON(jsonStores)` to prepopulate the stores before our initial render.

How does this sound?  Do you have some completely other way of doing this in mind?  :)

@rustyhodge The images on the site come in a variety of formats for different sizes. There is no consistency whether a given image is .jpg or .png for a given size and a given station. I definitely agree with you, but it would add not only complexity but additional load time to fetch images from the website. Also, image sizes are not optimized on the site. To get a png file for gslcassic I had to convert a jpg file and then compress the image with external tools. The image has been broken in this chrome extension since the appearance of the station gsclassic (my personal favorite). This merge request will fix that problem.

@rustyhodge the images used in the chrome extension are 120x120px png. However, your [channel xml feed](https://somafm.com/channels.xml) has a mix of png and jpg at that size. There is no consistency also with the naming of a given image. E.g., the Suburbs of Goa channel is suburbsofgoa but the 120px image is sog120.jpg; Space Station Soma is spacestation and sss.jpg. All the larger images are generally named after the station, but the 120px default images are not necessarily. The images sizes are fine on the site, at least for the half dozen I looked at. 

The thing is, every time a browser starts up, do you really want to have the xml file and 39 images requested? Having them packed in a simple chrome extension will keep its memory load and network latency low.

Why does the name of the file matter if it's referenced in the channels.xml/.json file? In theory they could be random strings. We change images and update images 

And why can't you cache the images, and see if they've been updated since last time it was opened? We send the Last-Updated time in the http header. But you will also need to check for files that have changed, and we swap things out sometimes as well.

And yeh I do want it checking for updated images every time it is opened. It's not different from opening our website front page.

There is a mix of PNG and JPG because we thought some looked better as JPGs and the PNG24s were too big. There might be some exceptions, like indychick.jpg ideally would be a PNG.

I hope you're checking the channels file when the extension is launched; stations come and go and that's the only way to know what's available.

I got an SSL error trying to get the current track from https://api.somascrobbler.com/api/v1/nowplaying/suburbsofgoa. https://somascrobbler.com/ is still up but the API it links to, http://api.somascrobbler.com/, also doesn't load.

Just for the record, SomaFM would prefer you don‚Äôt scrobble this. Last.FM is owned by CBS who uses that data for their own streaming. Not to mention CBS has been really harmful to indie broadcasters like SomaFM. We have had to send them cease and desists in the past for cloning our channels *and* using our names. Really uncool of them.

> We have had to send them cease and desists in the past for cloning our channels *and* using our names.

That is really shitty. üòû 

The thing stopping scrobbling from working seems to be the extension not knowing what song is currently being played. Even if scrobbling support is not restored, it would be ideal to see the current song or at least recently played songs on the active station. If the SomaScrobbler API remains down, I could do in this extension what I do in my standalone Electron app, which is pull the list of recent songs from api.somafm.com:

https://github.com/cheshire137/huxleyfm/blob/c038541b913948888f582bf803b1a5fcdd2f724d/models/soma.js#L26-L30

Just to note, I think it would be especially crappy to switch to using SomaFM's own API to get data and then use that data in a way SomaFM explicitly doesn't like. I think what I'll end up doing is dropping the dependency on the SomaScrobbler API and making this extension like [HuxleyFM](https://github.com/cheshire137/huxleyfm) in that it a) doesn't scrobble to Last.fm, b) gets its track data from the SomaFM API, and c) shows a list of the recent tracks from a station instead of showing one track that's currently playing.

Just chiming in to add that I also think it is awful how LastFM/CBS has affected SomaFM and I think it is a good decision to support @rustyhodge and SomaFM based on your decision to remove scrobbling. The LastFM API has been on life support for a while anyways, right? 

PS: Thanks for the hard work keeping this extension up to date. :100:

> The LastFM API has been on life support for a while

That's been my impression when I've gone to the Last.fm API page the last few times, yeah. I remember there was some trouble getting API keys I'd generated in the past.
Would it simplify things if I could give you a JSON or XML file that has only the currently playing song (and possible the time it started playing at)?

Thank you for the offer! Getting the recent tracks list per station is pretty easy using the endpoint that already exists, and it already includes a timestamp:

```json
{
	"id": "poptron",
	"songs":[
		{
			"title": "Frequent Flyer",
			"artist": "Chromeo",
			"album": "White Women",
			"albumart": "",
			"date": "1517442748"
		},
```

-- http://api.somafm.com/songs/poptron.json

I could see the duration of each track, if that's known, being added to this endpoint ‚òùÔ∏è. From the duration + the timestamp, I could determine if a track is still playing or not.

If durations for tracks aren't known, then an endpoint that has just the current song in a station would be useful, or if the track with the most recent `date` in the existing /songs/[channel].json endpoint is definitely the currently playing track, then I could use that knowledge.

What could be interesting, and maybe this is the format you were thinking instead of a separate endpoint per station, would be a single endpoint with a list of all the stations and the active song on each. Then in the extension, in addition to the station name, I could also list the song that's playing. That could help a user choose which station they want to listen to, especially if they recognize the song/artist being played.

It's up to you! I think the extension would be just fine using existing SomaFM API endpoints. üëå

I understand the problems with Last.fm. How about Libre.fm? It is a free software alternative to Last.fm. It might be worth considering to just switch services instead of dropping scrobbling support altogether. Just an idea.

No longer relevant since scrobbling support was removed.

This issue is caused by the different buffer amounts on some of our streamservers.

Buffers can be over 2 minutes currently (on the ice.somafm.com server pool; the shoutcast servers have 20-30 second buffers), we may change that in the future and we're also going to phase out the shoutcast servers and use Icecast only. The metadata within the stream is sync'ed to the buffers thought. The XML feed gets updated as we play songs, so due to the buffering, it may seem like we're posting songs before we play them.

I'd suggest waiting 2-3 minutes after a song change to scrobble it.

I think you may be running into rate limits üòû . The "Couldn't access the GitHub API" is a catchall error that I'd like to make more specific.

My hypothesis can be verified by going into the action editor and selecting "Enable Debug Log":

![screen shot 2017-02-24 at 1 30 06 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/934497/23315715/64374560-fa95-11e6-8fef-d01a607019d6.png)

From there, if you restart LaunchBar and open the Console application and grep for "launchbar", you should be able to see the raw JSON responses coming back from the API.

I was able to reproduce this by trying to search for an organization which has a considerable amount of repositories.

One way to fix this would be to set a limit in the [`Account.repositories()`](https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/blob/46595877bb8e81a8a03d89cc7354db48903c1e67/Contents/Scripts/account.js#L30-L84) logic. Right now it simply iterates over _all_ repositories, but this might diminish the usability üòî .

> My hypothesis can be verified by going into the action editor and selecting "Enable Debug Log":

This process is a little easier now that https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/pull/41 has been merged.

While this isn't showcased in the gif that you added in this post, I believe that the reason we're eating through the rate limit so quickly is due to the way that the suggestions script executes API calls.

Currently, when a user inputs text after say `atom/`, after every new character (`atom/a`, `atom/at`, etc), a new request is fired off before the first one can complete. This is not the case if you type `atom/` and then wait for the results to come back, because once they do, they've been cached.

I've written in to LaunchBar's support to see if there's any sort of mechanisms to "wait" until a user has finished typing and _then_ invoke the script. In the event there isn't such a mechanism, I've started a spike on "request locking" over in https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/pull/42 that I think might help.

> I've written in to LaunchBar's support to see if there's any sort of mechanisms to "wait" until a user has finished typing and then invoke the script.

Unfortunately no such feature exists in LaunchBar. I think the best case forward would be:

1) Limiting the number of results that are returned by LaunchBar (https://github.com/bswinnerton/launchbar-github/pull/43) - which unfortunately means that you won't be able to search for all repositories
2) Wait for GitHub to bump their GraphQL API limits, which will likely happen after they come out of ["early access"](https://developer.github.com/early-access/graphql/)

> 2) Wait for GitHub to bump their GraphQL API limits, which will likely happen after they come out of ["early access"](https://developer.github.com/early-access/graphql/)

This has happened! I've bumped the limits to `100` (which should make 3x less requests) as of 3b1ce899a1599f1f36ea8d4f471354eae444045d. I'm going to close this out for now, but if you see it again please feel free to reopen this issue, @jasonrudolph.

üëã @marcomasser,

Thank you for taking a look and being so kind to do so in pull request form üôè.

The screenshot in the body of this pull request is the "happy path". Here's the problem that I'm running into:

![github-launchbar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/934497/23286089/51ee3086-fa03-11e6-8555-7ee6c77faa2e.gif)

In this example, I'm trying to pass in a commit SHA to find the pull request that it corresponds to. Something that was introduced in #16. But ever since enabling [live feedback](https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/pull/30/files#diff-d44cc3f554233af40ce2089d64e6306aR38), the application doesn't zero-out the contents of the LaunchBar input between executions. In the gif, I start by opening up the GitHub action and pasting in a commit SHA, the browser is opened and everything works great üëå. But the next time that I open the GitHub action, the user input is still there, causing the action to immediately re-invoke the browser opening, and causing a loop.

The code paths that are being executed in the screenshot are above are as so:

1. The global `run()` function is called, originally with [no input](https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/blob/998d723165797b66f0022cdd24663b97575eb721/Contents/Scripts/default.js#L31), so the [default menu items are displayed](https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/blob/998d723165797b66f0022cdd24663b97575eb721/Contents/Scripts/default.js#L37)
2. The user pastes in a commit SHA, which [does not match](https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/blob/998d723165797b66f0022cdd24663b97575eb721/Contents/Scripts/default.js#L31) any of the titles of the default menu items, so [`displayMenuItemFor(input)`](https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/blob/998d723165797b66f0022cdd24663b97575eb721/Contents/Scripts/default.js#L59) is called
3. The `displayMenuItemFor(input)` function matches the input against a series of regular expressions to see what sort of menu item should be displayed. After checking a few regular expressions, it correctly [matches the input of the commit SHA](https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/blob/998d723165797b66f0022cdd24663b97575eb721/Contents/Scripts/default.js#L104-L110), instantiates a `Commit` object and calls `openCommitPullRequestsMenu(commit)`
4. An [API call is made](https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/blob/1a23e78c6834575cddf65eba0c008e8e55c007e4/Contents/Scripts/default.js#L168) to determine the commit's pull requests, if only one is returned, we [open up the link](https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/blob/1a23e78c6834575cddf65eba0c008e8e55c007e4/Contents/Scripts/default.js#L173) in the user's browser

This all works great. It's on the _next_ execution where things get a little funky.

On the second execution, the global `run()` function is called, but already has the commit SHA entered from the last time LaunchBar's GitHub action was run. This causes us to skip right to step 3, and repeat the process.

Now this, paired with `LaunchBar.executeAppleScript('tell application "LaunchBar" to hide');` (which was not enabled when I recorded the gif), gives the user no opportunity to hit escape, meaning that there's no way to clear out the contents of the user input, and makes the action unusable.

I hope this accurately explains the problem I'm facing. I think what I'm missing is a way to clear out the contents of the user's input in LaunchBar between executions when live mode is enabled.

> BTW: Why does LaunchBar go away at the end in the GIF? It looks like you press Esc twice (once to close the result item list and another time to hide LaunchBar).

Yes, that's exactly right. I think it was just habit üò¨ .

@marcomasser, I've figured it out! The issue was that I was calling `LaunchBar.openURL`, which doesn't play nicely with live feedback. What I've added in https://github.com/bswinnerton/github.lbaction/compare/30250dfcebcf5a7f91c686caeaf35efb207b8172...91173a7f20b4d38f1db1d6b33accef1ef6273c3c is a series of menu items that will appear so that the user can select them, instead of immediately opening the links as they type.

Thank you for the assistance ‚ù§Ô∏è .

@bswinnerton Thanks for the thorough explanation, now the GIF matches what I understood from the text and I see what you mean. You obviously found a usable workaround by now (not opening the URL right away, but showing a result item for the commit first). This looks really nice now!

It doesn‚Äôt seem to me that there‚Äôs anything we should change on LaunchBar‚Äôs side because the new behavior feels right to me. Do you agree?

Nonetheless, this begs the question whether we should add some functionality to LaunchBar that manipulates the user‚Äôs input. I can think of two possible solutions:

- Add an Info.plist key that specifies that before the action is called, the input should be cleared. In other words: Always start the text input with the empty string.

- Allow the action‚Äôs code to actually manipulate the user‚Äôs input. This is much more involved because the action‚Äôs code would need to be run, recognize that it‚Äôs run with *an old user input*, then modify the string and run again. Also, this could lead to usability issues because the user‚Äôs input isn‚Äôt just the user‚Äôs input anymore: It could be a transformed version of the input, which may be unexpected.

Seeing as the most likely use case would be to just clear out the old input, I think the first approach would definitely be sufficient.

@jasonrudolph, I suspect that you're hitting <kbd>‚åò</kbd> + <kbd>Enter</kbd> before launchbar-github has a chance to fetch all of the repositories that the Apple organization has access to via an API call to GitHub.

Here's a screen capture of an up-to-date version of launchbar-github that has already cached the result of Apple's repositories:

![swift-command-enter](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/934497/32147025-736fe08a-bcb6-11e7-9080-893c11315178.gif)

A terrible workaround is to wait for the repositories appear before hitting <kbd>‚åò</kbd> + <kbd>Enter</kbd>. But I've opened https://github.com/bswinnerton/launchbar-github/issues/87 to explore a better way of accomplishing this.

 ```yaml
jobs:
  build-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
     - name: Deploy to GH Pages üöÄ
        if: ${{ github.event_name != 'pull_request' }}
        # feature branch, without emoji - no warning message
        uses: MichaelCurrin/actions-gh-pages@description-remove-emoji
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: build

      - name: Deploy to GH Pages üöÄ
        if: ${{ github.event_name != 'pull_request' }}
        # main branch, with emoji - causes warning message
        uses: MichaelCurrin/actions-gh-pages@main
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: build
```

See triggering the repository_dispatch with curl and passing a client_payload...

```
curl \
    -H "Authorization: token ${GH_TOKEN}" \
    -H "Accept: application/vnd.github.everest-preview+json" \
    "https://api.github.com/repos/fawohlsc/github-runner-azure/dispatches" \
    -d "{\"event_type\": \"container-deploy\", \"client_payload\": {\"rg_name\": \"${RG_NAME}\", \"location\": \"${LOCATION}\"}"
```

and accessing client_payload in the GitHub Actions workflow...
```
name: Deploy as VM

on:
  repository_dispatch:
    types: vm-deploy   

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    
    steps:  
    - name: "Checkout GitHub repository"
      uses: actions/checkout@v2
    - name: "Login to Azure"
      uses: azure/login@v1
      with:
        creds: ${{secrets.AZURE_CREDENTIALS}}
    - name: Deploy GitHub Runner to Azure
      uses: azure/CLI@v1
      with:
        inlineScript: |
          chmod +x $GITHUB_WORKSPACE/vm/deploy.sh
          $GITHUB_WORKSPACE/vm/deploy.sh
      env:
        RG_NAME: "${{github.event.client_payload.rg_name}}"
        RG_LOCATION: "${{github.event.client_payload.location}}"
        GH_TOKEN: ${{secrets.GH_TOKEN_RUNNER}}
        GH_REPOSITORY: ${{github.repository}}
  
  test:
    runs-on: [self-hosted, Linux, Azure, VM]
    needs: deploy

    steps: 
    - name: "Test GitHub Runner on Azure"
      run:  |
        hostname -I | awk '{print "GitHub Runner Private IP:\t", $1}'
```

Few intermediate things that can be done to partially elivate refresh pain :)
1 - When the local repository push or pull do couple of refresh in period of 2-3 sec.
2 - If some job was marked running; maybe check every 30 sec in background only in that case.
3 - When the side panel gets back focus autorefresh.

Combination of 1 & 2 will be really helpful

I haven't written Java or Groovy in quite some time now. Any chance for a PR fix?

@cholick, I have just updated IDEA and was hitting the exact same problem too. Actually I use Spock and Geb a lot, but I have never written any IDEA plugins. In order to provide a bugfix PR, someone would have to introduce me to the internal structure of this plugin first. I am not sure if that would save you any time in comparison to fixing the plugin yourself and pushing an update to the plugin library. What do you think?

@leonard84, I think you are more experienced in all things Groovy and Spock than I. Do you see a chance to provide a PR? Or do you think another Spock committer would consider adopting this plugin? I think that even though Spock is a framework and not an IDE-related tool, it is essential that it is supported well by the major IDEs (IDEA, Eclipse, maybe Netbeans) in order to promote adoption and increase acceptance rate. For me personally IDEA is the most important, but other users might require IDE integration elsewhere. (Sorry for the meta comment.)
@fpape, you contributed to this plugin before. Can you maybe help to fix this? Sorry to disturb you, but without Spock support IDEA seems to be worth just half as much as before.

As far as I can see, simply rebuilding the plugin against the new version of IntelliJ IDEA will make it work again (it will pick up the changed return type of `ComponentManagerImpl.getPicoContainer()`).

I cloned the project earlier today but could not make it compile due to lots of undefined variables and paths to libraries I don't know how to configure. The read-me on the main page of this repository does not explain enough for an IDEA plugin newbie to be able to build the plugin. So if you get luckier, feel free to try. 

On a side note, I think JetBrains recommends to build plugins with Gradle. This project is just an IDEA project, so you cannot easily bootstrap it with a dependency management tool. BTW, I don't speak Gradle either, I am rather fluent in Maven.

Anyway, if we don't want to upload a fork even if someone manages to build the plugin, the original author ought to upload the (hypothetical) latest version with his own JetBrains account. Alternatively, someone could fork the plugin to just work on IDEA 2019.3+ and get rid of some old code supporting previous IDEA versions. But my favourite solution would be that someone with the necessary IDEA plugin + Spock knowledge volunteers as a maintainer and the plugin can stay the same and get upgraded and maybe also some bugs fixed or suboptimal syntax highlighting improved. But that's just me thinking out loud, not directly related to the problem at hand.

I tried again and somehow found a hacky way of building the plugin:
* As I only have the current IDEA version installed and the plugin supports multiple IDEA versions via adapters, I had to make all modules dependent on that IDEA plugin API. Due to this making complation of the IDEA 11 adapter impossible, I had to comment out some stuff there and also change one test class and one more application class a little bit in order to make it compile.
* When building the plugin JAR somehow many class files were missing, I had to manually add them to the JAR archive by copying them from the _out_ directory. I have no idea why IDEA's built-in menu entry messes up building a complete plugin JAR.
* I assigned my local plugin the version number _**0.11.1.hacky.kriegaex**_ in _plugin.xml_ just to differentiate it from the original.
* Most of the tests are failing. I have no idea if this also happens in the original project.

**But** the plugin is working for me in IDEA 2019.3 and seems to function normally. But I did not extensively test it.

One more finding when comparing the original 0.11 JAR from JetBrains plugin database to my own version was that all files and paths are identical, just the class files differ binarily.

Oddly enough, the original version contains files from package `com.intellij.uiDesigner.core`. Why they were copied into the JAR I have no idea. Maybe @cholick can explain that. My plugin version works without these files.

I think this plugin needs to be converted into a clean Maven or Gradle build rather than relying on IDEA project files checked into the GitHub repository. When cloning on a PC other than the author's, it can and will not work like this because of missing paths, dependencies etc.

Without any kind of warranty, here you can download my plugin version:
https://scrum-master.de/download/idea-spock-enhancements-0.11.1.hacky.kriegaex.jar

Open the plugin manager, click on the gear wheel icon beside "Marketplace" and "Installed", then select "Install plugin from disk..." and select the downloaded plugin. IDEA will then restart. After that probably the plugin will still be deactivated because IDEA remembers the deactivated state from the original version. Activate it and restart again. Then the plugin should be active again.

**Disclaimer:** My hacky plugin version is not meant as a permanent replacement of the original, but maybe it helps us all buy time until we get an update with an official build available via the JetBrains plugin marketplace.

Some historic context and background: the reason this doesn't use Maven or Gradle is because it pre-dates that method for plugin building. The only way initially to build plugins was through the IDE itself. It's awesome they've changed that: I tried to get it building via Gradle ages ago and eventually gave up, that flow just wasn't there and you needed the IDE itself to compile.

The adapter packages are probably less important now. Given it's been quite a few years and things have continued to "just work" until this release, those APIs are much more stable then when I initially wrote this. I built this when IntelliJ was doing a yearly release, and the underlying pieces I needed changed every single release. The the one mention of `ComponentManagerImpl.getPicoContainer())` changing does imply to me that one might still need two versions. It could be JetBrains plugin site makes that less relevant now, though, and just supporting the current version is "good enough"

The tests in the original project all worked last build.

I don't have any recollection of adding files from `com.intellij.uiDesigner.core`. Which file specifically? The commit message may jog my memory.

@kriegaex sorry, but Spock does consume my whole free programming time already. And the last time I tried doing an IDEA plugin I never got the build process working like I wanted it to. Maybe @masooh might want to help out, since he is already tinkering with another Spock related IDEA plugin, but he also has limited time.

@leonard84, I fully understand that you are busy and have to prioritise like everyone else too. But it was worth a try. ;-)

@cholick, by my suggestion to modernise the build and dependency management I did not want to blame you not to have used tools which were unavailable at the time you developed the plugin. What you explain makes a lot of sense to me. :-) But actually, as far as I understand the module structure, it should be possible to convert the project to a Maven build because actually you just need to build the modules and then package all the class files and resources into a JAR (or ZIP, which is basically the same). There even seems to be a rudimentary [IDEA plugin](https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/7127-intellij-plugin-development-with-maven/) to help with maintaining such a Maven POM, but I have not tried it. Even with plain vanilla Maven it would be easy to build, provided you don't mind maintaining _plugin.xml_ manually.

If I knew anything about Gradle, of course the official Gradle plugin would be preferable because it offers all kinds of perks to make plugin development easier.

As for your question, you can see for yourself by [downloading your own plugin](https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/7114-spock-framework-enhancements/versions) and inspecting its content. I am listing the files I found inside:

```none
com\intellij\uiDesigner\core\SupportCode$TextWithMnemonic.class
com\intellij\uiDesigner\core\Util.class
com\intellij\uiDesigner\core\VerticalInfo.class
```

I didn't bisect your Git repo in order to find out how they got in there, though.

The workaround is quite simple. Once the plugin is installed, go to `Preferences`, click the `Spock` item in the root, and change the color to `#A9B7C6`.

So that's where that option was, I was going through the code and created spockEnhancements.xml which has those 3 settings, and tried to put it in correct place, but gave up at some point. 
Turns out it is ~/Library/Preferences/IntelliJIdea14/options/spockEnhancements.xml

*My menu was little different, it was under "Other Settings>Spock".

Thanks

Very interesting.  When I open up your test project, I see proper highlighting for BigBrotherSpec, but the highlighting does NOT work for TestSpec. I am seeing similar behavior on IntelliJ 15.0.2 running on OSX (using Darcula theme).  The highlighting for spock labels sometimes works and sometimes does not work.  Most of the time, the highlighting works for some labels but them stops within the same test class.  For example, for a class that contains 3 tests, the highlighting might work as expected in the first test, part of the second and none of the third.

I configured the spock highlighting to use a bright red color with bold and italics.  To make it really stand out from the normal label highlighting which is white without bold or italics.  What I am seeing is that only the color is not changed.  Within a test class, all of the spock labels are bold and italic but the color is only applied part of the way though the file.

I believe that the cause of the issue might be due to a race condition between the IntelliJ's default highlighting for labels and the plugin's settings for spock highlighting.  The darcula theme sets the color for labels to a gray-ish color (A9B7C6) which is what I am seeing for some of the spock labels.  If I copy the theme and disable the explicit foreground color, then the spock labels are shown with the correct color.  I can also just change to the default theme which does not set an explicit foreground colors for labels as well to resolve the issue.

I'm seeing exactly the same results that quintonm just reported above.  If I use 'Darcula' theme, the color highlighting either doesn't work or works erratically.  If I switch the 'Intellij" theme, the color highlighting works.  If I modify the Darcula theme to remove the Groovy label color, the color specified by the spock plugin again works.  So that's at least a workaround.  Thanks for figuring that out quintonm.

This inspection should be disabled by default. In the [Spock documentation](http://docs.spockframework.org/en/latest/data_driven_testing.html) said:

```
Why isn‚Äôt @Unroll the default?

One reason why @Unroll isn‚Äôt the default is that some execution environments (in particular IDEs) expect to be told the number of test methods in advance, and have certain problems if the actual number varies. Another reason is that @Unroll can drastically change the number of reported tests, which may not always be desirable.
```

My 2c on this as a huge fan of this library: I really like the idea of the garbage collector, however things get complicated by the fact that it's not thread-safe, which means having a collector per-thread and preventing any sharing of objects across threads. If the collector was thread safe, there would be a significant advantage to its existence over memory pools, which is that it would massively simplify shared ownership of heap objects.

If you're doing shared ownership with objects allocated from a memory pool, you basically have to ensure architecturally that an object is returned to the pool at the correct time. With the garbage collector however, it'll just happen as soon as all the references are cleared, which is very useful. Doing multi-threaded GC is tricky though, and I can imagine it's not particularly feasible for a library like this.

If you do remove it, maybe you could verify compatibility, and add some integration tests, and maybe an example or two using: 

https://github.com/ivmai/bdwgc/

@rogers0, this should give you a good version bump for the next Debian package release:

```
$ objdump -x .build/src/libcork.so.16.0.3 | grep SONAME

```

I think the soname is correct according to the [libtool documentation](https://www.gnu.org/software/libtool/manual/html_node/Updating-version-info.html).  15 ‚Üí 16 was a backwards compatible change; i.e., anything that linked against libcork.so.15 would continue to work with libcork.so.16.0.1 as the installed library version.  You're generating a [symbols file](https://github.com/rogers0/libcork/blob/debian/debian/libcork16.symbols) in the Debian package so I think anything depending on any new symbols in 16 would pick up the correct Debian package version dependency.

That is, the "crazy calculation" here is trying to mimic what libtool [would do](http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/libtool.git/tree/build-aux/ltmain.in?id=722b6af0fad19b3d9f21924ae5aa6dfae5957378#n7042) for `-version-info 16:0:1`

If you can find any preprocessor macros that we could use to detect NDK r11c, then we could update the autodetection logic to not use `__thread` on that platform.  We already have a pthreads TLS implementation available as a fallback; we'd just have to tell `<libcork/threads/basics.h>` to use it.

```
Pkg.Desc = Android NDK
```

Yeah that will help if you want to skip libcork's autodetection and set all of the configuration macros yourself.  The autodetection logic purposefully only uses information that we can get via the preprocessor from the compiler toolchain itself, so that it works out of the box regardless of which build system you're using.  That does limit what it can detect, but also makes it easier to embed in other projects.

I have found a few dark corners of the IP address space where the cork rendering of IPv6 addresses containing IPv4 addresses is wrong and two where the result is dubious.

First the dubious cases.
1. `0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0` is a special IPv6 address, but is is also an IPv4 compatible IPv6 address under rfc 1993  Libcork renders it as `::`, but successfully parses `::0.0.0.0` and it might be possible to render `::` this way, as well.
2. The same applies to `0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1` which is also special and is rendered as `::1` but could be rendered as `::0.0.0.1`

There is a class of cases where libcork renders IPv6 addresses conforming to rfc 1993 incorrectly.
1. Addresses with the prefix `::/96` are IPv4 compatible under rfc 1993 and should be rendered as `::W.X.Y.Z`, however, if the W and X octets are zero, the first hextet of the IPv4 address is subsumed into the `::` i.e. `::0.0.1.0` renders as `::100`.

This can probably be fixed by adding an additional branch for a best.len of 7 along with the existing tests for a best.len of 6 and 5 with the `ffff` 6th hextet.  If the dubious case of `::1` is to be resolved as a non IPv4, this will also require special handling.

As noted in the issue, the code does not handle the IPv4 translated form of RFC 2765 `::ffff:0/96`, the IPv4 embedded form of RFC 6052 `64:ff9b::/96`, or the tunneling forms of RFC 5214.

Pushed up a patch that cleans up the rounding.  The `msec`, `usec`, and `nsec` functions now output both the seconds and fractional portions, so that we have a place to carry over if needed.  That way, rounding 0.999999 to milliseconds gives you 1.000, as expected.  The functions have also been renamed to include the word `round`, to make it clear that there's rounding happening when you do this translation.

This also means that the `%f` format specifier is no longer valid.  From the commit message:

> The width that you select for the fractional portion also affects the value that we render for the seconds portion.  So instead of a separate `%f` fractional specifier, the `%s` and `%S` specifiers now accept optional width specifiers to include the fractional seconds in the output.

> The rounding of time values is questionable, at best

I think this part is a red herring.  If you're using timestamps as fences, just compare the `cork_timestamp` instances directly.  They're just numbers, after all.  The only time that rounding is forced is in the `cork_timestamp_format` functions, which is strictly presentational.  And if you format two timestamps that you've also compared, then any rounding that occurs will be consistent with the comparisons.  (I.e., `(a < b) == (round(a) < round(b))`)

From the commit message:

> The new `cork_unique_id` type represents a unique identifier that is visible at compile-time.  You can use these identifiers as keys for extensible points in a plugin system, for instance; the identifiers themselves will be unique within a given execution of the program, and they'll each have a name associated with them to help produce useful debug and error messages.

The key point in there is that we can check whether two unique identifiers are the same at compile-time, as well as at run-time.  If you use `const char *` keys, it's hard to get compile-time checks (since there are no guarantees about whether the compiler will collapse equivalent string literals into single in-memory strings).
New patch changes the name from `cork_unique_id` to `cork_uid` per suggestion from @johnzachary.

With this patch, every hash table will start with at least 8 buckets.  And we don't ignore the `initial_size` parameter if you want to pre-allocate more than that.  We currently resize once the load factor reaches 5, so with the default starting size, at ~40 elements, we should resize to 64 buckets.
Actually, because of the integer calculations, the load factor has to reach 6 for the divison to produce a result > 5

I like this idea, but would tweak the API a bit.

Instead of an in/out parameter, I'd suggest a separate accessor function:

``` c
size_t
cork_hash_table_bucket_count(struct cork_hash_table *table);
```

That on its own might give you what you need.  After each mutator function, you'd call this to get the current bucket count, and compare it to the value from the previous call (instead of comparing to 0).

If you want to know precisely when a reallocation occurs, I'd go for a hook function:

``` c
typedef void
(*cork_hash_table_resized_f)(void *user_data, size_t old_size, size_t new_size);

void
cork_hash_table_add_resized_hook(struct cork_hash_table *table,
                                 cork_hash_table_resized_f resized, void *user_data);
```

Either of those would work, but the accessor function adds a second function call to each potentially modifying call.
The hook is more attractive on its face, but, if the size doubles as seems to be the case in reading the code, the signature might be more useful if it were

``` C
typedef void
(*cork_hash_table_resized_f)(void *user_data, size_t new_bucket_count, size_t new_entry_count);
```

That way, you can track both the density (loading) and bucket count with a single callback.  If you care (or if the previous size actually matters), you should be able to maintain that each time you get a callback.

Yet another alternative would be to add variants to the mutator functions that have the desired functionality, but this causes a proliferation of interface functions.

> Either of those would work, but the accessor function adds a second function call to each potentially modifying call.

True, but that means you only pay the price to grab the bucket count if you need to for profiling purposes.  (The function call won't be any more expensive than the `if` statement that we'd have to add to all of the mutators in the case of the in/out parameter.)

> the signature might be more useful if it were

Good call.  I'll throw `old_bucket_count` in there, too.

> (The function call won't be any more expensive than the `if` statement that we'd have to add to all of the mutators in the case of the in/out parameter.)

I don't think this is correct.  The function call will have to be made every time a mutator is called by a user tracking reallocations.  

The original intent was that the in/out parameter be optional and could  be left strictly alone unless reallocation was performed. If the optional parameter is the last one (I realize that C does not suffer these gladly, but they are used with the variable number of arguments mechanism), users not tracking reallocations are unaffected.  Users tracking reallocation add the parameter.  The only place it need be detected and used is in the reallocation code where the additional tests are likely to be insignificant relative to reallocating and rehashing the table.

This is effectively the same effort required to determine whether the hook needs to be exercised.  I suspect that the hook is preferable as the variable number of arguments methods are pretty kludgy from what I can tell.

I think that some of this discussion is a red herring.  In general, I don't want to examine every entry creation call.  I want a plausible explanation for time consuming behaviors.  By adding a reallocation count to the hash table data structure and a hash table statistics function that can be called to extract performance information for the table, we should be able to get this information at the end of a run.  Having looked at the code, I'd like to be able to get the entry and bin counts as well as the reallocation count.  It might be useful to track the collision statistics, as well since the reallocation trigger is an average entries per bin rather than a hard limit.  Since we traverse the entry chain in the rehashing process, we could at least get a high water mark with a triple <reallocation number, bin index, entry count> that would show how badly (or well) the collision chain management was performing. This should be fairly low cost since it only occurs when reallocation is needed and should not add significantly to its operation count.  If this should turn out to be prohibitive, we can get it by making a traversal in the statistics function and expect this to be called only once in the lifetime of the table.

An alternative might be to define several levels of debug with debug level 2 causing log messages when reallocation occurs. These messages might include collision chain information for the pre (and possibly post) reallocation entries at a still higher debug level.
See https://gist.github.com/JohnMcHugh/823161 for a statistics run.

I have been looking through the code of the hash tables some more.  Whether these observations matter or not depends greatly on the number of entries that actually appear in the tables and on the ratio of entry creation to entry lookup.

To a limited extent, some of these issues can be addressed by the profiler, but the costs of a given hash table may be difficult to determine.  

These observations are based on timings for runs that created a 2^20 entry hash table and showed that setting the initial bin count to avoid bin reallocation reduced the run time by about half.  I suspect that further reductions would follow by tuning the memory pool for the entries, as well.  Note that most of the reallocation time is spent in the last reallocation since there are more items to move then.

Observation 1:

Hash tables are relatively heavy weight for small aggregations.  There is a point at which a linear search is better. Above that, a binary search may be the next choice, and above that point, the hash table may be indicated.  Setting the default bin count at 8 (49 entries to the first reallocation) is probably never appropriate.  An initial bin count of 2^14 would allow nearly 100K entries before reallocation.  If we expect a million entries, 2^18 bins is a good starting point. With a linear collision search and unordered collision chains, a hash plus on the order of 5 - 6 comparisons (worst case seems to be 20 or so) is required to find an entry.  Linear search on an ordered list would probably be better up to 8-12 entries, binary search up to a few hundred.

Observation 2:

Using an unordered collision chain requires a search to the end to find whether an entry is present. Ordering the chain does not add to the cost since the comparisons on entry will occur anyhow.  On a lookup, we will find an existing entry in an unsorted chain, on average, after looking at half the entries, and discover a nonexistent entry only after looking at all of them.  If values in the collision chain are uniformly distributed in the key space, an ordered list will typically find both existent and non-existent entries in about the same number of comparisons, about half the chain length.

Observation 3:

A 4K memory pool block only gives us about 128 table entries if we assume 8 byte pointers at 4 pointers per entry: key, value, forward and back.  It might be better to allocate the memory pool in blocks that are more appropriate to the number of entries supported by the bin allocation.  This might result in an initial memory pool size of a megabyte or so to support 16K initial bins with no additional malloc calls.  If we are going to double the bin space at each table reallocation, we might want to treat the `mempool` blocks in a similar fashion.  This would ensure that `malloc` failures, if any, would only occur at table reallocation time.  In some use cases, recovery is possible by writing the existing table information to disk and clearing the existing table.

Note that it is not necessary to link the pool block space onto a free list.  The free list need only contain pool entries that have been allocated, then freed.  The free space in the pool block is contiguous and can be allocated from a single free pointer that is compared to a limit value to determine whether a new block is needed. If the free list is non empty, freed space is used preferentially, then unallocated block space, then a new block is allocated as necessary.  This avoids the performance hiccough that occurs when a linked list containing large numbers of items has to be created in the middle of an operation.

Observation 4:

It is not necessary to save the old bin space and allocate new space.  The existing space can be extended with `realloc` and the new bin pointer chains initialized with a `memzero` operation.  If the existing space is not extended, the `realloc` operation will copy the existing hash chain entries using an efficient `memcpy` operation.

The rehashing process essentially uncovers a new high order bin index bit for the existing hash collision chain entries. If this bit is `0`, the entry remains in its current hash chain.  If the bit is a '1', the entry is moved to the chain in a newly allocated bin.  On the average, we expect half the entries to stay put and half to move.  If the existing chains are ordered, the new chains can be created as ordered simply by traversing the existing chain in order and appending the moved entries to the ends of their new chains.

For the projects I'm using libcork with, I treat libcork as a separate package, built and installed as a shared library, and use pkg-config in my other source trees to make them link with libcork (along with any other shared libraries they depend on).

Your suggestion would also work ‚Äî it's definitely fine to extract out whatever files you need and embed them into your own source tree.  libcork is BSD-licensed, so the only constraint is that you need to include the copyright notice in the COPYING file when you copy things over.  I don't know of anyone who's done that yet, but it should be straightforward.  I don't know that it would need to be a separate git repo or anything; you'd just copy over the files that you need and include them in your own source repo.

If all you need is the dynamic array implementation, you might also want to look at [CCAN](http://ccodearchive.net/), which is another collection of helpful snippets of C code.  It's more cleanly broken down into discrete bits of functionality than libcork is.  They have a [dynamic array module](http://ccodearchive.net/info/darray.html) module that uses the same kind of macros that we use in libcork.  If you don't need all of libcork's other bells and whistles, you might find it easier to use CCAN.

Practically, what is the highest level of temporal resolution of interest to analysts? I see the need for sub-second resolution but don't know what real-world people consider overly precise.

This depends on 1) The resolution of the clock providing the timestamp, and 2) the speed of the capture, and 3) exactly how the clock is implemented and read.  This is not a decision that should be enshrined in the library, but should be available to the analytic developer.

Absolute synchronizations between clocks can be pushed into the sub-microsecond range, but milliseconds are more common. For observations made with respect to the same clock, the resolution needs to be sufficient to answer the question, "Did event A precede or follow event B?" for a pair of short events.  We need to be able to do this, even when the records order has been altered or the record aggregated with a preserved start time and duration.

Consider 500bit packets which is just about a minimum IP packet with an ethernet header.

At 1Gbs, these will reguire 500ns. Thus, there is a possibility that they could have the same microsecond timestamp, since we typically truncate rather than round, so 100ns is the requirement.

At 10Gbs, the packet takes 50ns, increasing the needed resolution to 10ns

at 40Gbs, we need 1ns resolution and at 100Gbs (not here, yet) we probably need the equivalent of 1 tick (~250ps) in a 32 bit fraction.

Now, most clocks can't really deliver this, but a few can.  There are also strictly monotonic clocks that guarantee at a one tick advance on successive reads, so the full clock resolution will work, even if the clock is slower than the optimum. (I 1microsecond resolution clock and display would work on the 1Gbs network since successive reads would differ by at least 1.

Just pushed up a patch that addresses this issue (finally).  The new `%[width]f` format specifier inserts the fractional portion of the timestamp's seconds.  So if you want Unix epoch plus microseconds, you'd use `"%s.%6f"`.

To do this I had to stop using `strftime` under the covers.  I haven't implemented all of the format specifiers that `strftime` supports; but I think I did get most of the ones that we'll need in practice.  If there are other obvious ones, I can add support for those.  Alternatively, we can add support for additional specifiers with new issues at some point in the future.  (I'd prefer the latter except for any specifiers that I missed that are glaringly obviously needed.)

While I was at it, I changed the API so that the functions now render into a `cork_buffer` instead of a preallocated `char` array.  More safe that way, since you don't have to calculate by hand how big that buffer needs to be, based on the format specifiers that you choose.

@JohnMcHugh wrote in Issue #16 (closed):

> Both the cork_timestamp_format_utc() and cork_timestamp_format_local() functions are capable of producing 
> time strings in the ISO 8601 format given the appropriate "const char *format" parameters. It would be useful if
> the libcork.h file included #defines to support and standardize this usage.
> 
> Adding definitions such as
> 
> `#define ISO_8601_BASIC_TIME "%Y%m%dT%H%M%S"` and
> `#define ISO_8601_EXTENDED_TIME "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S"`
> 
> would support this. If it is desired to explicitly include the local time zone or UTC designator in the time string,
> the character "Z" or the string "+00" can be appended to the conversion buffer before it is returned for the UTC
> case.
> 
> Adding "%z" to the format string will give the offset from UTC as +/-hhmm which works for the basic format, but
> would need to be edited to "+/-hh:mm in the extended case.
> 
> In addition to standard time representations, ISO 8601 defined a standard form for reporting durations. CORK 
> timestamps can be interpreted as durations (with the value representing seconds since the start of an event
> rather than seconds since the epoch beginning), but these cannot be explicitly created under the strftime rules.
> In addition, the standard sanctions using months and years in the duration representations but gives no guide
> on how these are to be computed. Were we to add explicit support for a CORK duration string, it should probably
> have weeks as its largest component since the length of months (and subsequently larger units ) is nominal. If
> the duration is computed by subtracting two timestamp values, the presence of a leap second can make even
> the day and week components of a duration nominal although ISO 31-1 defines a day as 84600 seconds.

That is fine, put you should rename the function cork_timestamp_format_iso8601() to something like cork_timestamp_format_iso8601_utc() to be consistent with the other cork_timestamp_format functions.
If you want to add function signatures for this, a macro defining cork_timestamp_format_iso8601_utc(ts, buf, size) as
cork_timestamp_format_utc(ts, "%FT%H:%M:%SZ", buf, size) would appear to be easier and you could similarly define the local version using  "%FT%H:%M:%S%z" which results in an +/-hhmm time zone (not actually sanctioned by the ISO standard and hh:mm would seem more consistent with the rest of the format, but it will carry the meaning.  Wrapping a little code around the _local call would let you drop the minutes if the mm portion of the offset is "00" - this is sanctioned for both basic and extended forms or edit it to insert a ":" if it is not.  In most cases, the TZ is whole hours.  Exceptions that I can find are Newfoundland, Iran, Afganistan, india, Burma, and mid Australia all of which have hh:30 offsets.

Please make sure the other issues raised in 16 do not get forgotten.  We will need support for duration display at some point and I do not think a single format will fit all needs.

#define cork_timestamp_format_local_iso8601(ts, bfr, sz) \
    while (1) {                         \
    cork_timestamp_format_local(ts, "%FT%H:%M:%S%z" bfr, sz);   \
    int be = strlen(bfr);                   \
    if (bfr[be - 1] == '0') {                   \
    if (bfr[be - 2] == '0') {               \

    } else if (bfr[be - 2] == '3') {            \
        bfr[be - 2] = ':';                  \
        bfr[be - 1] = '3';                  \
        bfr[be] = '0';                  \
        bfr[be + 1] = 0;                    \
    }                           \
    }                               \
    break;                          \
    }

We're using `inet_pton(3)` to parse the addresses, and its Linux man page gives the rationale for the parse error:

```
NOTES
       Unlike  inet_aton(3)  and inet_addr(3), inet_pton() supports IPv6 addresses.
       On the other hand, inet_pton() only accepts IPv4 addresses in dotted-decimal
       notation,  whereas inet_aton(3) and inet_addr(3) allow the more general num‚Äê
       bers-and-dots notation (hexadecimal and octal number  formats,  and  formats
       that  don't require all four bytes to be explicitly written).  For an inter‚Äê
       face that handles both IPv6 addresses, and IPv4  addresses  in  numbers-and-
       dots notation, see getaddrinfo(3).
```
Consensus seems to be that we should squash the Linux-style octal/parse error behavior like a bug.  We'll support leading zeroes, and parse all octets in decimal.

For one thing, I've tried to make the timestamp functions "line up" with functions that are available in the C library for `time_t` values. If we want support for arbitrary timezones, that will be a more involved change than just adding this one function.  We'd want to implement something like [pytz](http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pytz/) (along with [best practices](http://lucumr.pocoo.org/2011/7/15/eppur-si-muove/)), but in C.

If you use an array of masks and initialize them with CORK_UINT32_HOST_TO_BIG(0xffffffff >> i) for i in 0..32, you can simply do 

return addr->_.32 & mask[cidr_prefix] == 0;

The integer part of the union is the same storage as the array, so the storage overhead is simply 33 UINT32s and the initialization is a one time cost.

```
cc1: warnings being treated as errors
/Users/dcreager/git/libcork/src/libcork/core/ip-address.c: In function ‚Äòcork_ipv6_is_valid_network‚Äô:
/Users/dcreager/git/libcork/src/libcork/core/ip-address.c:204: warning: integer constant is too large for ‚Äòlong‚Äô type
```

The issue is with the 64-bit integer constants in the IPv6 function ‚Äî you'd need to add a `UL` or `ULL` suffix (depending on the platform) to the integer literal to silence the warning.  You can use the C99 `UINT64_C` macro to choose the right one automatically.  So `0xffffffffffffffff` would become `UINT64_C(0xffffffffffffffff)`.

Which I have done.

A-ha....I think I finally figured out what's happening here.  We end up using the `cork_error__tls_destroy` function inside of an `assert` call.  So if you're compiling the `Release` build type, in which assertions are left out, we never make the `pthread_key_create` call and we never use that function.  That's what I get for violating the "no side effects in an assert" rule.
This fixes the build problem. All tests pass.
